advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Maxi Basic Yeno SC 3000 : program at full gallop"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SORD BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Tim Mackay</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">... The 6800 will never win any beauty prizes. It is like the Model 'T' and the DC-3, not pretty but beautiful in function. It is simple, easy to use and maintain and does its job in the most reliable and economical way possible. What more could you want?</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Apple hardware advertisement.<br> From Personal Computing, October 1983 issue<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Isn't this a stupid advert ?!<br> Look carefully at each face !</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The Empire Strikes Back"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. 1983 #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Hard disk version<br><br> "<font color="#666666">No matter how you look at it, KAYPRO is the best value you will see anawhere...</font>"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACORN AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> Success in the future will depend upon confidence in using new technologies. That's why a computer in the home has to be more than just an interesting diversion or even a useful tool. It has to an investment in tomorrow for you and your children... </font> <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, SEPTEMBER 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Each day, go on the computing road''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPUTERS IN THE EXAM ROOM</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to the <a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">PC Leaflets Museum</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Your personnal computer for 670 F"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AMIGAWORLD PREVIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote>Thanks to Jun Suzuki <a href="http://member.nifty.ne.jp/tarucus/museum/cool/cool.htm">web site</a></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (MAY 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>for the Commodore PET 3001</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MBC-550 FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The personal computer 550, an opened door upon you computing future''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"TO8D, the smart present"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Yoann Riou for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> (FUNNY) PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>... from a promotional brochure</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (AUG. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says: <br><br><font color="#666666"> In other words, how to pop your office into a shoulder bag and then go out and about.<br> You see the Sharp PC7000 is no ordinary computer. Not only it is light, compact body packed with a much speed and power as most desk top computers, it's also very, very versatile... </font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tony Mattson for this picture</p></blockquote>

computer.coprocessor: 32 bit RISC Hitachi SuperH-1, 2x 32 bit custom VDPs (custom Video Display Processor 1+2), Motorola 68EC000 @ 11.3 MHz, custom SCU (Saturn Control Unit) @ 14.3 MHz, 4 bit Hitachi MCU (SMPC)
computer.description:
This version of the Saturn was produced by Victor (better known in the U.S. and Europe as JVC) under licence from Sega. It is functionaly identicle to the Sega version of the console, the only change is a different splash screen when the console is switched on.
There are two different versions of the V-Saturn:
V-Saturn (RG-JX1): This is the first version, released on November 22nd 1994. The top half is grey and the bottom half is black. It has oval buttons and uses both the 1.00 and 1.01 versions of the V-Saturn BIOS.
V-Saturn (RG-JX2): The second version, released June 7th 1996. The top half is grey and the bottom half is dark grey. It has round buttons and uses version 1.01 of the V-Saturn BIOS.
computer.name: V-Saturn
computer.ports: COM port, internal expansion port, AV Out, cartridge slot, power adapter, 2 controller ports
computer.sound: Yamaha FH1 (SCSP) @ 22.6 MHz, 32 PCM channels + 8 FM channels
